utterances: And I'm Robert Siegel.
There has been a lot of talk along the Mississippi coast about how to rebuild places devastated by Hurricane Katrina.
Experts from all over the country have come to explain their vision of what the coast should look like.
Cities are figuring out how to comply with new federal insurance regulations.
(Soundbite of immigration protestors)

People know those brands and they recognize those shows and they are thinking, well, gee, if I want to spend two minutes goofing off at work, am I going to download something that may or may not be funny, may or may not have a point?
Or am I going to spend those two minutes with David Letterman when I have a pretty good chance of, you know, being entertained and laughing.
And - so, it's not just the brand identification, though.
As people get used to higher production values, they're going to trend towards that.
I do think that's true.

I mean particularly the next evolution that we're going to see with video on the Internet is people being able to watch it on their TV, so kind of making a connection between the Internet video on their PC to the television set.

And what we're used to watching on our television is very high-quality material and so I think when you have the, you know, skateboard accident video or the cute kitty taking a nap video and it tends to be sort of lower quality, you're not going to want to watch that sitting in your living room when you've got a 100 channels of really high-quality content available.

And I understand we're talking about this in a specific content, but you just described broadcast television as really high content - quality content, which, in another context, you might want to take that back.
That's true.
You know, production values tend to be high.
You know, the camera isn't shaky, the, you know, the sound isn't fuzzy.
So it's high quality in that sense.
Not necessarily highbrow; I wouldn't describe it all that way.
Let's see if we can get some listeners involved in this conversation.
Again, our number is 800-989-8255, 800-989-TALK.
Our e-mail address is talk@npr.org.
And let's go to Andrew(ph).
Andrew calling us from Voorhees in New Jersey.
Hi.
How are you?
I'm good.
I actually host - I'm really interested in the topic that you are discussing.
I've actually talked about this with my friend.

I personally really enjoy watching like video podcasts that you find online, even more so than I -I don't even really watch broadcast television anymore, mainly because I think its pretty homogenized, pretty boring, and in many cases pretty stupid.
And I find that the amateur homemade video podcasts and videos that you find online, most of them are - can be very dumb but every once in a while you'll find one that's very clever, very witty.
And I really enjoy watching them.
So you're willing to go for a lower batting average but the occasional grand slam homerun off the steady diet of singles and doubles you might get off mainstream media.
Yeah.

I'm pretty tried of all the - I'm going to keep running with this baseball analogy - I'm tried of, you know, watching a bunch of ground balls, and then really not enjoying any moment of the time I spent watching broadcast television.
I really think it's going so downhill.
And every once in a while you'll find a specific podcast or you'll find person whose sense of humor really matches your own online.
And whereas on regular they really are produced to please the widest possible audience, which really means that it kind of makes it pretty boring for most people.
And, Scott Kirsner, what Andrew seems to be saying is he likes these tiny little niche broadcasters.
And I think a lot of people do.
I'm definitely not trying to deride the quality of a lot of what people are putting out or say that it's not going to exist.
I mean the Web turns out to be a great, very democratic publishing tool, whether you want to create a blog or create a podcast or create videos.
I'm just saying that I do think there's going to be mix of content that people watch.
You know, some people may watch more amateur contents; some people may watch less.
You know, it's interesting to think about the split is today.

If you think about the time you spent on the Web, how much are you spending with a site like a CNN or The New York Times or an ESPN site, and how much time are you spending, you know, reading your friends blogs?
For most people, their friends' blog haven't taken over 100 percent of their Web surfing.
You know, the big media companies still have a share of that.
And I think the same will be true with video.
And you also raise the question of - by the way, Andrew, thanks very much for the call.
Thank you.
You raised the issue of the semi-professional, the sort of third category in between, you know, the CBS and Aunt Millie.
I do think that semi-professionals can be a really interesting category, and so those are people that are making video today.
You know, maybe they are making travel videos in Hawaii about things you can do in Hawaii.

Or they are making instructional yoga videos in Montana and they really didn't before the Internet have a way to get those videos out to the world and potentially charge money for them, potentially put advertising around them to make some money.
So I think the semi-pro is going to be really interesting.
And the other piece of that category is people who haven't really been video producers but are really, really got at making amateur videos.
And we have seen a lot of those come up on YouTube and sites like Revver.com.
And those people I think will sort of fill out the semi-pro category and kind of get discovered.
And by the way, whenever we mentioned this site, we always get e-mail questions.
YouTube is spelled Y-o-u-T-u-b-e, all one word and don't go to that other Web site run by some plumbing company.
Let's get Bob in Detroit.
Bob in Detroit is on the line with us.
Hi.
How are you doing?
Thanks for taking my call.
Sure.
I just wanted to say that my comment was that I think the premise that amateur videos are going to go away as the pro-videos come online, it doesn't make any sense.
It's ridiculous.

I think that the same people that were watching the amateur videos and posting amateur videos in the first place could still go watch the pro contents that are on MSNBC.com or just on CNN if they wanted to.
Yeah, that's right.
And I think that as the pro stuff comes in I don't really see a reason for anybody to stop watching or posting the amateur stuff.
To compare the old days of movies with the new days, it's like saying, you know, when - whatever the first stuff that came out on DVD was, that would be it.
And, you know, the guy with the card trick would, you know, would take over anything.
I don't think anybody ever did say that.
I don't think that Scott Kirsner is saying the amateurs are going to go away entirely, either, but let's let him respond for himself.
Well, yeah.
I mean if you think about - if you were someone who was using the Web in the early days, you know, 1994, '95, '96, there weren't a lot of really well made professional Web sites out there.

And so you find yourselves spending a lot of time visiting someone's pictures of their dog on their homemade Web site or - I remember there are a lot of universities that would put up, you know, information about, you know, was the coffee pot freshly made on the fifth floor of the university, you know, computer science center.
And people went to these Web sites because there wasn't a whole lot else available.
And I think that's kind of what we've been seeing in the last year with video is that, you know, there kind of was a vacuum of professionally created content on the web.
And so a lot of people jumped to the conclusion that this is going to be a medium dominated by amateurs, and I just don't think that's going to play out long term.
Bob, thanks very much.
I don't think anybody predicted that it would be predominantly taken over or run by the amateur.
I think everybody pretty much knew it's just a matter of time before the ad dollars hit, but that's my comment.
Thanks for taking my call.
It's a great comment.
All right.
Bob, thanks very much.
We're talking today with Scott Kirsner, whose op-ed appeared in yesterday's San Jose Mercury News.
If you'd like to read a copy to it, there's a link at our Web page.
You can go to NPR.org and go to the TALK OF THE NATION page.
And remember that all of our recent Opinion Page segments can be downloaded as podcasts, and damn popular they are too.
Just stop by the TALK OF THE NATION page at NPR.org.
And this is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
And as you get this debate, I mean it's not going to be all or the other as you suggest, Scott Kirsner.
It's not going to be that there are no more exploding two-liter bottles of Diet Pepsi on the Web.
No, I don't think that stuff is going to go in.

I really do think the thing that's going to be so interesting about the video landscape going forward is that you'll occasionally have that rocket-out-of-the-blue kind of hit where someone discovers that when you drop a Mentos candy into a 2-liter bottle of Diet Coke crazy things happen.

And I think that's going to force both the big media companies to be more creative about what they put on the Web and maybe less formulaic; and it's going to force, you know, the folks who are making video in their backyard or their basement to be just really clever and really funny and really unique in what they create.
And I do think, you know, we've seen some examples of that.
The one that I like to cite is the JibJab videos that people will remember from the 2004 elections, and those are some of the most watched videos of all time on the Internet.
I think between the two of them, one was called ""This Land"" and the other is called ""Good to be in D.C."" about Bush and Kerry.
They were both seen 80 million times, or 85 million times, so that's a pretty big audience.
And those were made by two, you know, wannabe animators down in L.A.
who really had never had a big media connection or big media deal before.
And suddenly everyone knows the brand JibJab, and most people I think in America have seen those videos, which were kind of a genre.
You know, it's like Schoolhouse Rock mixed with The Capitol Steps.
You know, it was a genre - maybe mixed with a little South Park - it was a genre that no one had really ever seen before, sort of this animated, political satire musical stuff.
Let's get Jeff on the line.
Jeff calling from Phoenix.
Yeah.
I just wanted to say that ultimately I don't think it's ever going to be the technology anymore as the issue.
I mean the technology has caught up, and it will.
We're going to have better and better cameras, easier to use, better computers.
It's really going to be the content.
I mean I'm a musician and I've got a recording system that The Beatles would have killed for.
But it doesn't mean I'm going to produce good music.
It's going to be what's in it, the creativity and the talent that really rises to the top, whether it's considered amateur or professional.

And I think your point, Scott Kirsner, is if you add up all the degrees of talent, including all of the equipment that Jeff was talking about but also writing, acting and videography skills, professionals have an edge.
